name: 英語名著選讀與批判研究
goals: 轉化任教學科專業知識
善用學習評量促進學生學習
追求以教師專業成長為導向的生涯發展
對於教學進行反省，創造教育的價值
syllabus:
**Schedule**

**W1**/Sept. 28    **Course overview**. What is “Classics”? Why study classics?

**Introduction** to course and the selected readings of educational classics

**W2-5               Part One: The 1930s – 1940s**

Oct. 05          Dare the school build a new social order (1932)/George Counts

Oct. 12          Democracy as a way of life (1937)/Boyd Bode

Oct. 19          Experience and education (1938)/John Dewey

Oct. 26          Basic principles of curriculum and instruction (1949)/Ralph W. Tyler

**W6-9               Part two: The 1960s – 1970s**

 Nov. 02          The process of education (1960)/Jerome Bruner

 Nov. 09          Life in classrooms (1968)/Philip Jackson

 Nov. 16        Pedagogy of the oppressed (1969)/Paulo Freire

 Nov. 23          Ideology and curriculum (1979)/Michael Apple

**W10-13         Part Three: The 1980s – 1990s\***

(Students can select other important contemporary readings for this part)

 Nov. 30          The Paideia proposal: An educational manifesto (1982)/Mortimer J. Adler

 Dec. 07          A place called school (1984)/John I. Goodlad

 Dec. 14          The dialectic of freedom (1988)/Maxine Greene  

 Dec. 21          The challenge to care in schools (1992)/Nel Nordings

**W14** /Dec. 28  (Self analytical study)

**W15**/Jan. 04    **Final paper report**

**W16**/Jan. 11    Review and Feedback

The assignments in this schedule are subject to change throughout the semester. Revisions will be announced in class and posted on Moodle.

methodologies.note: Introduction to course and the selected readings of educational classics
to read the selected educational classics and participate in class discussions
to conduct an analytical study on a chosen educational classics related to personal research interest; and to submit the report (position paper) and to present it to the class.
to do 3 critical reflections on their chosen readings of educational classics;

grading.note: Each student of the class will choose a classics selected from each time period (all together three) to write up personal critical reflections and to share with class members in class.
Each student of the class is expected to complete the assigned reading before coming to class and to take an active role in class discussions as both participants and discussion leaders.
Each student of the class will plan an analytical study on a chosen classics to demonstrate understandings and critiques on the classics with supporting arguments from the related literature.

prerequisite: ◎Unavailable for M.A. program students (M.A. program courses excepted) and B.A. program students.
